title: England football news: Bulgaria's newspapers react to the racist abuse of England players
text:
The Three Lions' clash against Bulgaria in Sofia was marred by racist chanting

The Bulgarian press have reacted to the racist abuse of England players in the Euro 2020 qualifying match on Monday night.

The Three Lions' clash against Bulgaria was marred by racist chanting and the game had to be halted twice by UEFA officials due to the abuse.

Debutant Tyrone Mings complained to referee's assistant Bojan Zobenica that he had been targeted in the 22nd minute. Monkey chants were heard whenever Raheem Sterling and Marcus Rashford were on the ball and home fans were seen making fascist salutes.

England player's were subjected to horrific racist abuse by Bulgaria fans during their 6-0 win

There were two breaks in play in Sofia after racist chanting was reported to the match officials. Bulgaria fans are pictured making monkey noises

The behaviour of Bulgaria fans was met with widespread outrage and condemnation by players on the field and spectators

A headline on Bulgarian news outlet VESTI on Tuesday morning read: 'Shame in Sofia - a major topic in the UK. Borisov wants Mikhailov's resignation.'

The prime minister of Bulgaria has demanded that the country's FA president steps down over the shocking racist treatment that England's black players were subjected to.

Bulgarian PM Boyko Borisov says the government will freeze all relations with the Bulgarian FA - including denying them any funding - until football chief Borislav Mihaylov steps down.

The Bulgarian press have reacted to the racist abuse of England players on Monday night

While in an article on Bulgarian outlet Dnes it read: 'Experts: UEFA is looking for a black sheep,' and an article on Trud read: 'We ourselves are guilty'.

England manager Gareth Southgate was heckled by a Bulgarian journalist in his press conference following his side's 6-0 win.

A Bulgarian reporter labelled the accusations of racism as 'absolutely not true' during Southgate's post-match press conference.

Anti-discrimination group FARE (Football Against Racism in Europe) will help UEFA build a 'legally safe' case to prosecute Bulgaria.

Players and manager Gareth Southgate gather around the match referees to alert them about the horrific abuse the black players were being subjected to
